awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Division of Chemistry, Professors Kelly Chacon of Reed College and Steven Townsend of Vanderbilt University are organizing a workshop that seeks to provide new chemistry faculty insight into the proposal writing and reviewing process so that they can identify and develop strong research, education and outreach activities. Faculty beginning their independent careers often find the process of writing their first grant proposals to be challenging. Participants will have the opportunity to network with each other as well as with successful grant recipients and federal program officers from a variety of agencies. The participants will engage in mock panels, research presentations, and other activities designed to provide them with a better understanding of how to put together a research plan that is ambitious, yet realistic and compelling. Broader impact criteria will also be discussed including educational activities, outreach, broadening participation and longer term application to societal problems. 

The 2021 Chemistry Early Career Workshop, supported by the Division of Chemistry will be held on May 17-18, 2021 in a virtual format. This workshop will bring together up to 100 junior faculty from a broad range of institutions and demographics to discuss steps in strategically crafting research ideas, planning educational and outreach activities, achieving excellence through diversity and assessing and evaluating project aims. Potential participants can access more information as it becomes available at a publicly-facing web page.  Inquiries will also be receivable through a dedicated email address (nsfworkshop2021@gmail.com).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This funding request was for Dr. Steven Townsend and Dr. Kelly Chacón to host a workshop, supported by NSF CHE, targeted at early career investigators in a diverse range of CHE-supported areas. The workshop provided early career chemists with opportunities to network with: each other, funded mid-career NSF researchers from a variety of institutions, and program officers from NSF CHE and other organizations supporting chemistry research. The workshop was designed to help participants gain a better understanding of the funding landscape, with a particular emphasis on the NSF CAREER program; as well as give advice and tools to help participants better integrate research and education goals, select funding channels, and self-evaluate research ideas, projects, and plans. This two- day event took place over May 17-18, 2021, and was modeled on the successful events held in 2018 and 2019. Hosting this event virtually safely enabled the participation of many program directors and also provided the 55 attendees with the opportunity to visit the NSF and follow up with specific program directors before or after the workshop. The workshop was designed to serve up to 100 participants and was be open to investigators performing research in NSF-supported disciplines within the United States.

Of the 39 participants who completed the post workshop survey, ~95% gave either a high score of 4 (12.8%) or the maximum of 5 (82.1%) to the question "This workshop provided beneficial skills/knowledge". Additionally, the 39 respondents overwhelmingly reported that the workshop felt inclusive, welcoming, and that they felt much more confident in either first time proposal submission or re-submission to NSF-CHE programs. 

Notes for future iterations of this workshop included: Reverting to in person format in order to increase networking and cohort building among the applicants while allowing those who cannot travel the option to remotely attend; increasing the time to prepare for and conduct the mock review panels; and a robust means of facilitating applicant writing groups to form after the workshop. Additionally, many attendees remarked upon the favorable interactions with and wisdom of the program officers who provided their time. Finally, at the end of the workshop many attendees remarked that they would recommend this workshop heartily to other early career PIs and that it was extremely useful. 


Last Modified: 09/13/2022
Modified by: Kelly N Chacon
